article:
'Advanced NFL Stats' is a website dedicated to the analysis of the National
Football League using advanced mathematical and statistical methods.
The site's lead author is noted football researcher and analyst Brian
Burke. {{cite news|url= http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/arti-
cles/2009/11/17/belichick_had_the_numbers_on_his_side/|title=Belichick Had the
Numbers on His Side|accessdate=2010-03-08|publisher=The Boston Globe |
first=Adam | last=Kilgore | date=2009-11-17| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org-
/web/20100121130934/http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/articles/200-
9/11/17/belichick_had_the_numbers_on_his_side/| archivedate= 21 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} Burke is a regular contributor to
the New York Times NFL coverage, the Washington Post's
Redskins coverage, and supplies research for other notable
publications and writers.

Advanced NFL Stats features a variety of analytical techniques and applications.
The site predicts game outcomes and rates teams using a logistic regression
model based on team efficiency statistics. It also features a live in-game win
probability model that estimates the chances either opponent will win a game in
progress. Advanced NFL Stats uses its win probability model to analyze strategic
coaching decisions such as whether to kick or attempt first down conversions.

Research topics include game theory applications, luck and
randomness, {{cite news|url= http://fifthdown.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/24/jets-were-one-of-the-luckiest-
teams/|title=New York Times-Jets Were One of the Luckiest Teams| accessdate=2009-01-
17|publisher=nytimes.com | first=Toni | last=Monkovic | date=2008-12-24|
archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090129105927/http://fifthdown.blogs.ny-
times.com/2008/12/24/jets-were-one-of-the-luckiest-teams/| archivedate= 29
January 2009 | deadurl= no}} play calling, home field
advantage, run-pass balance, and the relative importance of various facets of
performance (offensive passing, offensive rushing, defensive passing, etc.).
Also featured is research on weather factors, team payroll, and the NFL Draft.

The site has pioneered other analytical concepts such as Air Yards, which is the
distance forward of the line of scrimmage that a pass travels. It removes the
contribution of Yards After Catch (YAC) run by a receiver.

Advanced NFL Stats also features a catalog of unique individual player stats.
Each player's contribution toward his team's wins, known as Win Probability
Added (WPA), is available for each season since 2000. Expected Points Added
(EPA), success rate (SR), and many other innovative metrics are available.

During the NFL off-season, Burke has posted original research related to other
North American professional sports leagues. {{cite news|url= http://blogs.wsj.com/dailyfix/2009/04/27/the-count-refining-the-concept-of-a-
must-win-game/|title=The Wall Street Journal, "The Count: Refining the Concept
of a Must-Win Game"| accessdate=2009-04-287|publisher=wsj.com | first=Carl |
last=Bialik | date=2009-04-27}}
